author: acid0003
content:
How often and how long do eth devs usually keep actively abused exploits secret without fixing them?
"We've known about this vector for a bit (possibly from the authors). Fixing it in a simple way may or may not introduce additional unforeseen issues. Given that we're in the final stretch for replacing PoW with PoS, we've felt it't not worth risking a fix for a marginal gain for a marginal time span." - karalabe (regarding the uncle maker exploit)

author: killari.
content: Thats a good research topic. I would think in generally in IT security, years?

author: acid0003
content: Generally in IT security exploits are fixed immediately regardless if they are abused. If they are actively being exploited, the fix or a mitigation is released immediately.

author: killari.
content: do you have data on this claims?

author: killari.
content: why is it that there's years old malwares still going around and not fixed?

author: acid0003
content: I call BS on your claim, please provide a single example where there was a known exploit with malware abusing that exploit, which was not fixed or at least revealed immediatly?

author: acid0003
content:
https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/v4.18/admin-guide/security-bugs.html
 As a basic default policy, we expect report date to release date to be on the order of 7 days.

author: acid0003
content: It sounds like you are claiming that Ethereum devs commonnly learn about an exploit and observe it being exploited for years before they reveal it?

author: killari.
content: any virus that is currently in wild. It would not be in wild if the issue were not fixed

author: killari.
content: no I am not, where did you read that?

author: acid0003
content: You need to educate yourself on security

author: killari.
content: this is policy that everyone can make, not everyone would follow it

author: acid0003
content: do you have more FUD/trolling? or are you all out?

author: killari.
content: sure, what do you want to hear?

author: acid0003
content:
I find your ideas intriguing and I would like to subscribe to your newsletter.
Also, I am waiting for you to provide a single example of malware that was exploiting a vulnerability that was still undisclosed a month after it was known to be exploited.

author: acid0003
content: all of the CVEs that I have found were fixed immediately and disclosed within months (none were exploited to my knowledge)

author: killari.
content: you changed the goal post?

author: acid0003
content:
https://geth.ethereum.org/docs/vulnerabilities/vulnerabilities#:~:text=As%20of%20November%202020%2C%20our,the%20details%20about%20the%20vulnerability.
"In the software world, it is expected for security vulnerabilities to be immediately announced,"

author: acid0003
content: Yep, I made it easier for you, a month instead of a year

author: acid0003
content: I will settle for a week, even a business day is a long time

author: killari.
content: no yu changed it to the disclosing and not fixing

author: killari.
content: now you required both

author: acid0003
content: I said 'revealed immediatly'

author: acid0003
content: You have demonstrated that you do not know the first thing about security, and have yet to provide any proof to support your claims.

author: killari.
content: I said any virus that is currently or have been wild in the past.

author: acid0003
content: Please provide a single example

author: killari.
content: ILOVEYOU

author: acid0003
content: You think that being able to attach files to email is an exploit?

author: killari.
content: no I don't think its an exploit

author: acid0003
content: is the ability for users to run programs an exploit?

author: killari.
content: not sure what you are after with these questions

author: acid0003
content: what is the exploit that ILOVEYOU abused?

author: killari.
content: I don't think it abused any exploits

author: acid0003
content: you are correct that today I can email you a program and you can still run it

author: gwintery
content: There should be a R&D channel for human behaviour soon at this rate

author: acid0003
content: so, I go back to my original question, please give me an example of malwhare that abused an exploit that was not revealed/fixed quickly after the exploit was observed in the wild?

author: killari.
content: the same one? I think we are going in loops in this discussion, so its not really useful anymore

author: acid0003
content: is your next example going to be the Stay Puff Marshmallow Man?

author: acid0003
content: it also did not exploit anything, and was not fixed/announced after it was observed in the wild

author: killari.
content: no I am not. I don't find this discussing useful anymore so its better that we just stop :)

author: acid0003
content: You have made a claim that "Thats a good research topic. I would think in generally in IT security, years?" regarding How often and how long do eth devs usually keep actively abused exploits secret without fixing them?

author: acid0003
content: and you have provided zero evidence to support this, and shown that you have zero experience related to the topic

author: killari.

author: killari.

author: killari.

author: acid0003
content: and you are the first one I am aware of to suggest that we go back to computers that cannot run new programs

author: killari.
content: where did I suggest that?

author: acid0003
content: then you have not provided an example

author: killari.
content: right. Lets not continue this discussion, have a nice day

author: acid0003
content: wow, the troll was overfed :D

content: well, you don't know anything about security, so I will ignore your feedback

author: acid0003
content:
How often and how long do eth devs usually keep actively abused exploits secret without fixing them?
"We've known about this vector for a bit (possibly from the authors). Fixing it in a simple way may or may not introduce additional unforeseen issues. Given that we're in the final stretch for replacing PoW with PoS, we've felt it't not worth risking a fix for a marginal gain for a marginal time span." - karalabe (regarding the uncle maker exploit) 

according to the go-ethereum policy on disclosing vulnerabilities, it makes no mention of how to handle actively exploited vulnerabilities that "if exploited, would harm the Ethereum mainnet"
 https://geth.ethereum.org/docs/vulnerabilities/vulnerabilities#:~:text=As%20of%20November%202020%2C%20our,the%20details%20about%20the%20vulnerability.

Does Ethereum have a vulnerability disclosure statement that is similar to go-ethereum, and what is the stance on keeping vulnerabilities secret if they are seen on the network?

author: yam09253
content: hi, anyone know what is the scheduled date/block for the eth difficulty time bomb

author: acid0003
content:
If you need a date, September/October. But it is not a specific date when it blows up. Over a time period of months the time in-between blocks will increase more and more rapidly.
https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-5133

author: acid0003
content: also, the uncle maker attack includes its own difficulty bomb that could go off any day

author: yam09253
content: thanks much.  From a eth 2.0 roadmap perspective, does the bomb have to start ticking BEFORE the actual merge (sep 19) or can it happen after

author: killari.
content: its ticking all the time, it just grows exponentially

author: acid0003
content: merge (or a fork) needs to happen before the bomb gets so bad that eth stops working

author: yam09253
content: hmm, according to eip-5133 above, bomb will start at block 15530314

author: acid0003
content: but that is prob like october to december for different definitions of broken

author: acid0003
content: the bomb does almsot nothign for a month

author: acid0003
content: look for a difficulty graph and you can see the previous bombs

author: killari.
content: yeah, it will start to grow a lot at that point, but before that its just insignificant

author: killari.
content: thats how exponential distribution works :)

author: yam09253
content: üëç  so, for POW chain to work, Geth, Erigon and other codebases will have to fork to at least remove the bomb, correct?

author: killari.
content: depends which nodes you want to run in the forked network, generally you want all the node software to implement the change

author: acid0003
content: the bomb is basically a stranglehold the devs put on ethereum to prevent another eth classic

author: acid0003
content: they force the network to upgrade at regular intervals, and they are the devs so they have a lot of sway in what upgrade is done

author: acid0003
content: and simpy running the existing software is not an option

author: killari.
content: this is not the intention. The difficulty bomb was there then as well and it did not stop eth classic and that was not even wanted
